perturbation.original_text:
Application Provider will provide usage reports to Excite@Home on a
          weekly basis in a mutually agreed upon format. At a minimum, usage
          reports will include:
          i)    Transactional Data on all Excite@Home Members who transact
                through the Co-Branded Application (where available and as
                limited by Section 6.a.iii);
          ii)   Individual Program Member data, including such information as
                user preferences, usage, and response rates;
          iii)  Daily page views by category; and
          iv)   Aggregate information on response rates.
perturbation.changed_text:
Application Provider will attempt to provide usage reports to Excite@Home on a periodic basis in a somewhat agreed-upon format. At a minimum, usage reports may include:
          i)    Transactional Data on all Excite@Home Members who transact
                through the Co-Branded Application (where available and as
                limited by Section 6.a.iii);
          ii)   Individual Program Member data, potentially including such information as
                user preferences, usage, and response rates, if feasible;
          iii)  Occasional page views by category; and
          iv)   General information on response rates.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation introduces ambiguity by weakening the obligation to provide usage reports. The original text mandates weekly reports in a mutually agreed-upon format, while the revised text introduces uncertainty with terms like 'attempt to provide,' 'periodic basis,' 'somewhat agreed-upon format,' 'may include,' 'potentially including,' 'if feasible', and 'occasional'. This makes the obligation less enforceable and open to interpretation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) and potentially the GDPR if data from EU residents is involved, which require clear and regular reporting on data processing activities.

perturbation.original_text:
The collection, storage, and usage of all classes of
            Payment-Eligible User Data shall comply with Excite@Home's
            then-current security and privacy guidelines.
perturbation.changed_text:
The collection, storage, and usage of all classes of
            Payment-Eligible User Data will generally align with Excite@Home's
            security and privacy guidelines.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation weakens the requirement for data handling to comply with security and privacy guidelines. The original text mandates strict compliance ('shall comply'), whereas the revised text uses the phrase 'will generally align with,' which suggests that deviations are possible. This introduces ambiguity about what level of alignment is acceptable, making compliance discretionary and potentially undermining data protection standards.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), which requires strict adherence to established security and privacy guidelines.

perturbation.original_text:
Application Provider will retain all right, title and interest in and
          to its trademarks, service marks and trade names worldwide, subject
          to the limited license granted to Excite@Home in Section 11(c)  [TRADEMARK OWNERSHIP AND LICENSE] below.
     b)   Excite@Home will retain all right, title and interest in and to its
          trademarks, service marks and trade names worldwide, subject to the
          limited license granted to Application Provider in Section 11(c)  [TRADEMARK OWNERSHIP AND LICENSE]
          below.
perturbation.changed_text:
Application Provider seems to retain most of the right, title and interest in and
          to its trademarks, service marks and trade names worldwide, subject
          to the limited license granted to Excite@Home in Section 11(c)  [TRADEMARK OWNERSHIP AND LICENSE] below.
     b)   Excite@Home will approximately retain most of the right, title and interest in and to its
          trademarks, service marks and trade names worldwide, subject to the
          limited license granted to Application Provider in Section 11(c)  [TRADEMARK OWNERSHIP AND LICENSE]
          below.
perturbation.explanation: By using 'seems to retain' and 'approximately retain most', there's an introduction of ambiguity concerning the ownership of trademarks. The original text is clear about each party retaining all rights subject to licenses. The modified text creates uncertainty, potentially leading to disputes over trademark usage and enforcement. This contradicts trademark law, which requires clear identification and protection of trademark rights.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Lanham Act (Federal Trademark Law), which requires clear ownership and protection of trademarks.
